intro: Zygostates chaparensis, commonly known as the Chapare mountain fern, is a rare and endemic species found primarily in the high-altitude regions of Bolivia. It belongs to the family Blechnaceae and is characterized by its delicate, feather-like fronds that are typically less than 30 centimeters in length. The plant thrives in cool, moist environments, often growing on rocky substrates or in shaded forest understories. Its reproductive structures, including spore-producing sorus, are located on the underside of the fronds, a feature common among ferns. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, Zygostates chaparensis is considered a vulnerable species facing threats from habitat loss and climate change.
